I think that driving should be for 20 and above, and let's make the test so hard that 70% of them don't pass the first time.  20 should be fine for military too. If you can take your life and the lives of those around you in your hands when behind the wheel, then you can be expected to fire a weapon in the correct direction. You're also still malleable enough to be trained to kill, and your cardio probably ain't  that bad. 

But as for voting, Service guarantees citizenship. You want to vote? Honorably complete a term of service of no less than six years.  No voting if you're still in the service, and none of this "everyone gets a vote" nonsense. If you put your life on the line for earth, you earn the right to participate.
Same with running for public office. Only citizens can run. Therefore, nobody under the age of 26 can be elected. 


...Would you like to know more?

body:
I do not agree. I think that people should be able to have sex starting at the age of 20. I think that at that age, people are mature enough to have safe sex and to responsibly choose their partners. I feel as though that waiting until the age of 25, when we are most mature, would be irresponsible because it would it harder to attract sexual partners before the age of 30. Sure, you can wait until marriage, but in this day and age, who's really doing that anymore? Basically, we would have to be having kids later. Waiting until 25 has it's upsides, like a reduced rate of teenage/young adult pregnancy and a lower std rate, but it has it's downsides. In South Korea, they have actually banned internet porn and have the age of consent at 20, so I agree with South Korea on this issue.

Also, still upvoted btw.

post.title: Real unpopular opinion:  If age of consent is supposedly based on ability to make mature decisions, then the only logically and scientifically consistent age for it to be set at is 25

author.bio: I do not care about your capacity to be offended.
author.bio_html: I do not care about your capacity to be offended.

body:
OP, what do you mean by maturity? Is it an anatomical property alone? That seems to be your point of view, but maturity isn't bound to anatomy alone. This post reads a bit likes Roganology. No offense, Joe has some good qualities, but does a lot of oversimplifying.  

There are issues with looking at maturity through an anatomical lens alone. One of those issues-- a person can have an anatomically mature brain and still have poor reasoning, low IQ, high impulsivity, etc. We see plenty of man-child 40 year old men, living with mom, evidencing this claim.

The anatomical maturing of an organ isn't the be-all-end-all. There is a philosophical side to maturity as well. It is very evident that some individuals reach higher levels of philosophical maturity before reaching anatomical maturity. As there are 40 year old man-children, there are also stoic, focused 20 year old men and women with high IQ, low impulsivity and excellent reasoning. 

Maturity isn't single axis and we probably shouldn't treat it as such, but it takes a lot of effort to add another axis, which makes legislation more difficult and less clear. It's actually a very tough problem to solve, that's why people accept throwing a fixed number at it like 16, 18, 21, 25.

Edit: great post by the way

body:
That would be the true age of consent, however because we begin to sexually mature between the ages of 11 and 14, age of consent is set by each culture. The United States currently has a prolonged adolescence, so while 21 used to be considered the Age of Majority,  it was lowered to 18. 
Personally,  I think 18 is a decent age of sexual consent,  but I think that there should be a soft increase in responsibility between 18 and 25. I also cut people in the early 20s a lot of slack. I think a lot of major decisions should be discouraged until around 25, including plastic surgery,  marriage, kids. And I think a responsible society guides it's young people towards sound decisions,  while also allowing them to make mistakes. It's an imperfect balance,  but life is imperfect.

body:
Oh, I wasn't advocating for mandatory conscription. And my comment about it seeming like a war was intended to be tongue-in-cheek, illustrating my own Naiveté when I enlisted at 18. Trust me, I've done my reading when it comes to military history.

The "service guarantees citizenship" comment was a reference to the book Starship Troopers by Robert Heinlein, in which both citizenship and the right to vote are granted only to veterans who voluntarily signed up for the service. This was also tongue-in-cheek, as the book is essentially a description of a global totalitarian society.
body_html:
Oh, I wasn't advocating for mandatory conscription. And my comment about it seeming like a war was intended to be tongue-in-cheek, illustrating my own Naiveté when I enlisted at 18. Trust me, I've done my reading when it comes to military history.

The "service guarantees citizenship" comment was a reference to the book Starship Troopers by Robert Heinlein, in which both citizenship and the right to vote are granted only to veterans who voluntarily signed up for the service. This was also tongue-in-cheek, as the book is essentially a description of a global totalitarian society.
